case_name: Bhaurao Shankar Lokhande and Deorao Shankar Lokhande v. State

facts.text: This is Criminal Appeal No. 178 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Criminal Appeal No. 178 of 1963. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 19, 1963, of the Bombay High Court in Criminal

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 19, 1963, of the Bombay High Court in Criminal Revision Application No. 388 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 19, 1963, of the Bombay High Court in Criminal Revision Application No. 388 of 1963. G. Patwardhan and M. S. Gupta, for the appellants. S. Barlingay, B. R. G. K. Achar for R. H. Dhebar, for respondent No. 1.

facts.text: Bhaurao Shankar Lokhande, appellant No. 1, was married to the complainant Indubai in about 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Bhaurao Shankar Lokhande, appellant No. 1, was married to the companyplainant Indubai in about 1956. He married Kamlabai in February 1962, during the lifetime of Indubai. Deorao Shankar Lokhande, appellant No. 2, is the brother of the first appellant.

facts.text: Appellant No. 1 married Kamlabai in February 1962 during the lifetime of Indubai.

anchor.surface_text: He married Kamlabai in February 1962, during the lifetime of Indubai. Deorao Shankar Lokhande, appellant No. 2, is the brother of the first appellant. These two appellants, together with Kamlabai and her father and accused No. 5, a barber, were tried for an offence under S. 494 I.P.C.

facts.text: Deorao Shankar Lokhande, appellant No. 2, is the brother of appellant No. 1.

anchor.surface_text: Deorao Shankar Lokhande, appellant No. 2, is the brother of the first appellant. These two appellants, together with Kamlabai and her father and accused No. 5, a barber, were tried for an offence under S. 494 I.P.C. The latter three were acquitted by the Magistrate.

facts.text: Appellants 1 and 2, together with Kamlabai, her father and accused No. 5 (barber) were tried for offence under S. 494 I.P.C.

anchor.surface_text: These two appellants, together with Kamlabai and her father and accused No. 5, a barber, were tried for an offence under S. 494 I.P.C. The latter three were acquitted by the Magistrate. Appellant No. 1 was companyvicted under S. 494 I.P.C. and appellant No. 2 for an offence under S. 494 read with S. 114 I.P.C.

facts.text: Kamlabai, her father and accused No. 5 were acquitted by the Magistrate.

anchor.surface_text: The latter three were acquitted by the Magistrate. Appellant No. 1 was companyvicted under S. 494 I.P.C. and appellant No. 2 for an offence under S. 494 read with S. 114 I.P.C. Their appeal to the Sessions Judge was dismissed.

facts.text: Appellant No. 1 convicted under S. 494 I.P.C. by Magistrate.

anchor.surface_text: Appellant No. 1 was companyvicted under S. 494 I.P.C. and appellant No. 2 for an offence under S. 494 read with S. 114 I.P.C. Their appeal to the Sessions Judge was dismissed. Their revision to the High Court also failed.

facts.text: Appellant No. 2 convicted under S. 494 read with S. 114 I.P.C. by Magistrate.

anchor.surface_text: and appellant No. 2 for an offence under S. 494 read with S. 114 I.P.C. Their appeal to the Sessions Judge was dismissed. Their revision to the High Court also failed. They have preferred this appeal by special leave.

facts.text: Appeal to Sessions Judge dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: Their appeal to the Sessions Judge was dismissed. Their revision to the High Court also failed. They have preferred this appeal by special leave. The only companytention raised for the appellants is that in law it was necessary for the prosecution to establish that the alleged second marriage of the appellant No. 1 with Kamlabai in 1962 had been duly performed in accordance with the religious rites applicable to the form of marriage gone through.

facts.text: Revision to High Court failed.

anchor.surface_text: Their revision to the High Court also failed. They have preferred this appeal by special leave. The only companytention raised for the appellants is that in law it was necessary for the prosecution to establish that the alleged second marriage of the appellant No. 1 with Kamlabai in 1962 had been duly performed in accordance with the religious rites applicable to the form of marriage gone through.

facts.text: Appellants contend that prosecution must establish second marriage duly performed with essential ceremonies.

anchor.surface_text: The only companytention raised for the appellants is that in law it was necessary for the prosecution to establish that the alleged second marriage of the appellant No. 1 with Kamlabai in 1962 had been duly performed in accordance with the religious rites applicable to the form of marriage gone through. It is urged for the appellants that the essential ceremonies for a valid marriage were number performed during the proceedings which took place when appellant No. 1 and Kamlabai married each other.

facts.text: State urges second marriage in accordance with custom of gandharva form in community.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the State it is urged that the proceedings of that marriage were in accordance with the custom prevalent in the companymunity of the appellant for gandharva form of marriage and that therefore the second marriage of appellant No. 1 with Kamlabai was a valid marriage.

facts.text: State urges not necessary for s.494 IPC that second marriage be valid; any form during lifetime of first wife suffices.

anchor.surface_text: It is also urged for the State that it is number necessary for the companymission of the offence under S. 494 P.C. that the second 8 39 marriage be a valid one and that a person going through any form of marriage during the life-time of the first wife would companymit the offence under s. 494 I.P.C. even if the later marriage be void according to the law applicable to that person.

facts.text: Essential ceremonies invocation before sacred fire and saptapadi not performed at second marriage.

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed that these two essential ceremonies were number performed when appellant number 1 married Kamlabai in February 1962. There is numberevidence on record to establish that the performance of these two essential ceremonies has been abrogated by the custom prevalent in their companymunity.

facts.text: No evidence to establish custom abrogating essential ceremonies in community.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberevidence on record to establish that the performance of these two essential ceremonies has been abrogated by the custom prevalent in their companymunity. In fact, the prosecution led numberevidence as to what the custom was.

facts.text: Second marriage ceremony at 10 p.m.: wooden sheets brought, carpet spread, accused 1 sat on one, accused 3 on other nearby, accused 4 performed puja with tambya pitcher, betel leaves and coconut on it, garlands exchanged by accused 1 and 3, struck each others forehead.

anchor.surface_text: What took place that night when appellant number 1 married Kamlabai, has been stated thus, by P.W. 1 The marriage took place at 10 p.m. Pat-wooden sheets-were brought. A carpet was spread. Accused number 1 then sat on the wooden sheet. On the other sheet accused number 3 sat. She was sitting nearby accused number 1. Accused number 4 then performed some Puja by bringing a Tambya- pitcher. Betel leaves and companyonut was kept on the Tambya. Two garlands were brought. Accused number 2 was having one-and accused number 4 having one in his hand. Accused number 4 gave the garland to accused number 3 and accused number 2 gave the garland to accused number 1. Accused number. 1 and 3 then garlanded each other. Then they each struck each others forehead.

facts.text: PW1 stated in cross: Gandharva not necessarily in temple, no Brahmin priest required, no Mangala Ashtakas chanted, no Brahmin called.

anchor.surface_text: In cross-examination this witness stated It is number that Gandharva according to our custom is performed necessarily in a temple. It is also number that a Brahmin Priest is required to perform the Gandharva marriage. No Mangala Ashtakas are required to be chanted at the time of Gandharva marriage. At the time of marriage in question, numberBrahmin was called and Mangala Ashtakas were chanted.

facts.text: PW2: custom not to perform at maternal uncle's house so done elsewhere; no custom for Brahmin priest; custom father makes foreheads touch to complete Gandharva.

anchor.surface_text: Sitaram, witness number 2 for the companyplainant, made a similar statement about what happened at the marriage ceremony and further stated, in the examination-in-chief Surpan is the village of accused number 3s maternal uncle and as the custom is number to perform the ceremony at the house of maternal uncle, so it was performed at another place. There is numbercustom requiring a Brahmin Priest at the time of Gandharva. He stated in cross-examination A barber is number required and accused number 5 was number present at the time of marriage. There is a custom that the father of girl should make to touch the foreheads of the girl and boy to each other and the Gandharva is companypleted by the act.

facts.text: Court finds prosecution failed to establish marriage performed per customary rites under s.7 Hindu Marriage Act or essential requirements.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the prosecution has failed to establish that the marriage between appellant number 1 and Kamlabai in February 1962 was performed in accordance with the customary rites as required by s. 7 of the Act. It was certainly number performed in accordance with the essential requirements for a valid marriage under Hindu law.

facts.text: Second marriage not solemnized under s.17 Hindu Marriage Act, so s.494 IPC not applicable.

anchor.surface_text: It follows therefore that the marriage between appellant number 1 and Kamlabai does number companye within the expression solemnized marriage occurring in S. 17 of the Act and companysequently does number companye within the mischief of S. 494 P.C. even though the first wife of appellant number1 was living when he married Kamlabai in 1 February 1962.

facts.text: Appeal allowed, convictions set aside, appellants acquitted.

anchor.surface_text: The result is that the companyviction of appellant number 1 under s. 494 I.P.C. and of appellant number 2 under s. 494 read with s. 114 I.P.C. cannot be sustained. We therefore allow their appeal, set aside their companyvictions and acquit them. The bail bonds of appellant number 1 will stand discharged.

anchor.surface_text: Section 494 I.P.C. reads Whoever, having a husband or wife living, marries in any case in which such marriage is void by reason of its taking place during the life of such husband or wife, shall be punished with imprisonment of either descrip- tion for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.

concepts.interpretation: Interpreted to require the second marriage to be valid in form but void due to bigamy; mere cohabitation or invalid ceremony insufficient.

Section 17 provides that any marriage between two Hindus solemnized after the companymencement of the Act is void if at the date of such marriage either party had a husband or wife living, and that the provisions of ss. 494 and 495 I.P.C. shall apply accordingly.

issues.text: We may now determine what the essential ceremonies for a valid marriage between the parties are

anchor.surface_text: We may now determine what the essential ceremonies for a valid marriage between the parties are. It is alleged for the respondent that the marriage between appellant No. 1 and Kamlabai was in gandharva form, as modified by the custom prevailing among the Maharashtrians.

It was certainly not performed in accordance with the essential requirements for a valid marriage under Hindu law.

It is urged for the appellants that the essential ceremonies for a valid marriage were not performed during the proceedings which took place when appellant No. 1 and Kamlabai married each other.

arguments.court_reasoning: 'Marries' in s.494 means valid marriage void only by bigamy; requires solemnization under s.17 HMA

arguments.claim: Expression 'whoever marries' in s.494 IPC means valid marriage, void solely by reason of subsisting spouse; invalid marriage not within section

anchor.surface_text: Prima facie, the expression whoever marries must mean whoever marries-validly or whoever marries and whose marriage is a valid one. If the marriage is number a valid one, according to the law applicable to the parties, numberquestion of its being void by reason of its taking place during the life of the husband or wife of the person marrying arises. If the marriage is number a valid marriage, it is numbermarriage in the eye of law.

arguments.claim: Mere living as husband and wife or holding out as such does not constitute marriage

anchor.surface_text: The bare fact of a man and a woman living as husband and wife does number, at any rate, numbermally give them the status of husband and wife even though they may hold themselves out before society as husband and wife and the society treats them as husband and wife.

arguments.claim: Under s.17 HMA, bigamous marriage void only if solemnized after commencement of Act

anchor.surface_text: Section 17 provides that any marriage between two Hindus solemnized after the commencement of the Act is void if at the date of such marriage either party had a husband or wife living, and that the provisions of ss. 494 and 495 I.P.C. shall apply accordingly. The marriage between two Hindus is void in view of s. 17 if two conditions are satisfied  i  the marriage is solemnized after the commencement of the Act at the date of such marriage, either party had a spouse living.

arguments.claim: 'Solemnize' means to celebrate marriage with proper ceremonies and in due form; requires performance per applicable law

anchor.surface_text: The word solemnize means, in connection with a marriage, to celebrate the marriage with proper ceremonies and in due form, according to the Shorter Oxford Dictionary. It follows, therefore, that unless the marriage is celebrated or performed with proper ceremonies and due form it cannot be said to be solemnized. ... We are of opinion that unless the marriage which took place between appellant number 1 and Kamlabai in February 1962 was performed in accordance with the requirements of the law applicable to a marriage between the parties, the marriage cannot be said to have been solemnized

arguments.claim: Essential ceremonies for valid Hindu marriage are invocation before sacred fire and saptapadi, even for gandharva form unless modified by custom

anchor.surface_text: It may be noted that the essential marriage ceremonies are as much a requisite part of this form of marriage as of any other unless it is shown that some modification of those ceremonies has been introduced by custom in any particular community or caste. ... There are two ceremonies essential to the validity of a marriage, whether the marriage be in the Brahma form or the Asura form, namely-  1  invocation before the sacred fire, and  2  saptapadi, that is, the taking of seven steps by the bridegroom and the bride jointly before the sacred fire.

arguments.claim: Essential ceremonies of invocation before sacred fire and saptapadi not performed at second marriage

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed that these two essential ceremonies were number performed when appellant number 1 married Kamlabai in February 1962.

arguments.claim: No evidence that custom in community abrogated performance of essential ceremonies

anchor.surface_text: There is numberevidence on record to establish that the performance of these two essential ceremonies has been abrogated by the custom prevalent in their community. In fact, the prosecution led numberevidence as to what the custom was.

arguments.claim: Witness statements on ceremonies performed and forehead touching do not prove they suffice under custom without evidence abrogating essentials

anchor.surface_text: Such a statement does number mean that the custom of the community deemed what took place at the marriage of the appellant number 1 and Kamlabai, sufficient for a valid marriage and that the performance of the two essential ceremonies had been abrogated. There ought to have been definite evidence to establish that the custom prevalent in the community had abrogated these ceremonies... In the absence of a statement by the witness himself that according to custom these ceremonies were the only necessary ceremonies for a valid marriage, we cannot construe the statement that the touching of the foreheads completed the gandharva form of marriage

arguments.claim: Recent changes (5-7 years) to ceremonies do not constitute custom under s.3 HMA requiring continuous and uniform observance for long time

anchor.surface_text: Further, Jeebhau has stated that about five or seven years earlier the performance of certain ceremonies which, till then, were essential for the marriage, were given up. If so, the departure from the essentials cannot be said to have become a custom, as contemplated by the Hindu Marriage Act. Clause  a  of s. 3 of the Act provides that the expressions custom and usage signify any rule which, having been continuously and uniformly observed for a long time, has obtained the force of law among Hindus in any local area, tribe, community, group or family.

arguments.claim: Prosecution failed to establish marriage performed per customary rites under s.7 HMA or essential requirements

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the prosecution has failed to establish that the marriage between appellant number 1 and Kamlabai in February 1962 was performed in accordance with the customary rites as required by s. 7 of the Act. It was certainly number performed in accordance with the essential requirements for a valid marriage under Hindu law.

arguments.claim: Second marriage not solemnized under s.17 HMA, hence not void and s.494 IPC inapplicable

anchor.surface_text: It follows therefore that the marriage between appellant number 1 and Kamlabai does number come within the expression solemnized marriage occurring in S. 17 of the Act and consequently does number come within the mischief of S. 494 P.C. even though the first wife of appellant number1 was living when he married Kamlabai in 1 February 1962.

holdings.text: Prima facie, the expression 'whoever marries' in Section 494 IPC must mean whoever marries validly or whose marriage is a valid one; if not valid according to applicable law, it is no marriage and cannot be void by reason of bigamy.

anchor.surface_text: Prima facie, the expression whoever marries must mean whoever marries-validly or whoever marries and whose marriage is a valid one. If the marriage is number a valid one, according to the law applicable to the parties, numberquestion of its being void by reason of its taking place during the life of the husband or wife of the person marrying arises.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of 'marries' and 'void by reason of' requires the marriage to be otherwise valid; mere invalid ceremony or cohabitation insufficient.

holdings.text: The bare fact of a man and woman living as husband and wife does not give them the status of husband and wife.

anchor.surface_text: The bare fact of a man and a woman living as husband and wife does number, at any rate, numbermally give them the status of husband and wife even though they may hold themselves out before society as husband and wife and the society treats them as husband and wife.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Status of marriage requires legal formalities, not mere repute or cohabitation.

holdings.text: For Section 17 HMA to render a bigamous marriage void (attracting S.494 IPC), it must be a 'solemnized' marriage, meaning celebrated with proper ceremonies and in due form according to applicable law.

anchor.surface_text: Section 17 provides that any marriage between two Hindus solemnized after the companymencement of the Act is void if at the date of such marriage either party had a husband or wife living, and that the provisions of ss. 494 and 495 I.P.C. shall apply accordingly. ... We are of opinion that unless the marriage which took place between appellant number 1 and Kamlabai in February 1962 was performed in accordance with the requirements of the law applicable to a marriage between the parties, the marriage cannot be said to have been solemnized

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dictionary meaning of 'solemnize' plus statutory context requires proper ceremonies; links HMA to IPC bigamy.

holdings.text: Essential ceremonies for validity of Hindu marriage (including Gandharva form) are invocation before sacred fire and saptapadi, unless abrogated by custom in the community.

anchor.surface_text: It may be noted that the essential marriage ceremonies are as much a requisite part of this form of marriage as of any other unless it is shown that some modification of those ceremonies has been introduced by custom in any particular companymunity or caste. ... There are two ceremonies essential to the validity of a marriage, whether the marriage be in the Brahma form or the Asura form, namely-  1  invocation before the sacred fire, and  2  saptapadi

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows authoritative text (Mulla's Hindu Law); applies to all forms unless custom proved.

holdings.text: These two essential ceremonies were not performed in the second marriage, and there is no evidence that custom in the community abrogated them.

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed that these two essential ceremonies were number performed when appellant number 1 married Kamlabai in February 1962. There is numberevidence on record to establish that the performance of these two essential ceremonies has been abrogated by the custom prevalent in their companymunity.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Undisputed fact plus failure of evidence on custom; witness statements insufficient to prove abrogation.

holdings.text: Prosecution failed to establish that the second marriage was performed in accordance with customary rites under S.7 HMA or essential requirements of Hindu law.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the prosecution has failed to establish that the marriage between appellant number 1 and Kamlabai in February 1962 was performed in accordance with the customary rites as required by s. 7 of the Act. It was certainly number performed in accordance with the essential requirements for a valid marriage under Hindu law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Review of evidence shows no proof of sufficient rites or custom; recent changes (5-7 years) not 'long time' per S.3 HMA.

holdings.text: The second marriage does not come within 'solemnized marriage' in S.17 HMA, hence not void under it, and S.494 IPC inapplicable despite living first wife.

anchor.surface_text: It follows therefore that the marriage between appellant number 1 and Kamlabai does number companye within the expression solemnized marriage occurring in S. 17 of the Act and companysequently does number companye within the mischief of S. 494 P.C. even though the first wife of appellant number1 was living when he married Kamlabai in 1 February 1962.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Logical consequence of prior holdings on solemnization and proof failure.

holdings.text: Convictions under S.494 and S.494 r/w S.114 IPC cannot be sustained; appeal allowed, acquittal.

anchor.surface_text: The result is that the companyviction of appellant number 1 under s. 494 I.P.C. and of appellant number 2 under s. 494 read with s. 114 I.P.C. cannot be sustained. We therefore allow their appeal, set aside their companyvictions and acquit them.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of above legal conclusions to facts leads to insufficiency of prosecution case.

anchor.surface_text: The result is that the conviction of appellant number 1 under s. 494 I.P.C. and of appellant number 2 under s. 494 read with s. 114 I.P.C. cannot be sustained. We therefore allow their appeal, set aside their convictions

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed; convictions under s. 494 I.P.C. and s. 494 read with s. 114 I.P.C. set aside; appellants acquitted
directions: The bail bonds of appellant number 1 will stand discharged

anchor.surface_text: Section 17 provides that any marriage between two Hindus solemnized after the companymencement of the Act is void if at the date of such marriage either party had a husband or wife living, and that the provisions of ss. 494 and 495 I.P.C. shall apply accordingly. ... We are of opinion that unless the marriage which took place between appellant number 1 and Kamlabai in February 1962 was performed in accordance with the requirements of the law applicable to a marriage between the parties, the marriage cannot be said to have been solemnized

anchor.surface_text: It may be noted that the essential marriage ceremonies are as much a requisite part of this form of marriage as of any other unless it is shown that some modification of those ceremonies has been introduced by custom in any particular companymunity or caste. ... There are two ceremonies essential to the validity of a marriage, whether the marriage be in the Brahma form or the Asura form, namely-  1  invocation before the sacred fire, and  2  saptapadi

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the prosecution has failed to establish that the marriage between appellant number 1 and Kamlabai in February 1962 was performed in accordance with the customary rites as required by s. 7 of the Act. The result is that the conviction of appellant number 1 under s. 494 I.P.C. and of appellant number 2 under s. 494 read with s. 114 I.P.C. cannot be sustained. We therefore allow their appeal, set aside their convictions
